translation: Fufazang yinnian zhuan, vol. 4

source_sentence: 元魏西域三藏吉迦夜共曇曜譯
translation: Yuanwei Western Region Tripiṭaka Jikāyai co-dharma-translation

source_sentence: 阿恕伽王復有一子名曰法增。
translation: "Again, King Asoka had a son named Fazen.
He had a wonderful eye that was well-balanced in appearance and correctness.
Then there was a bird named Kunala.
Its eyes were clear and pure, and it resembled that son.
He therefore called this son Kunala.
He grew up to be his wife, and her name was Zenjin Garland.
The king sent his son to Kukkuṭumārāma.
The elder monk, Yaśas, knew he would lose his eyesight.
He told him.

source_sentence: 眼者無常會當摩滅不可恃怙。
translation: "Eyes are impermanent, will cease in time, and can't be relied upon.
It's better to make effort and seek superior liberation.'
He was then taught by Komnara to return to the palace.
He observed that the eye was suffering, empty, and decaying.
The king's wife was named Tiṣya Rākṣa.
He became extremely attached to Komunala.
The fires of desire were raging, and they were forced to have sexual intercourse.
The prince's nature was always chaste.
He was resolute in his resolve and wouldn't obey him.
Tizhārakṣa became very angry with him.

source_sentence: 時拘那羅治在得叉尸羅城內。
translation: At the time, Kanakamuni was staying in the city of Takṣaśīla.
The great lady there was always waiting for his convenience.
It happened that the king was very ill and distressed.
The lady treated him and found a cure.
She vowed to take the king's place for seven days.
After she was granted the request, she then wanted to take revenge.
She secretly ordered him to write a letter to pick his eyes.

source_sentence: 王子奉教求一惡人令出右眼置掌而觀。
translation: The prince was instructed to ask a bad man to take out his right eye, put it in his palm, and look at it.
He then remembered what Yaśas had originally admonished him to do.
He then said.
"It's true, Your Eminence!
It's true and not false.
It says that the eye is impermanent and like an illusion.
In the past, this eye was said to be strange and marvelous.
Today, how can I be attached to it when I deeply examine it?
I will abandon this dangerous and decaying dharma.
I'll focus on seeking the most excellent, pure eye of wisdom.
When I observe it this way, I'll become a stream entrant.
I'll then take another glance and deeply contemplate it.
They become disillusioned with evil feelings and arrest the once-returner.
His wife, a golden garland, heard that her husband had poked his eye out.
She wept and came crying in tears.
She was drowning in tears after seeing him for a long time, but then she recovered.
Kunala then spoke a verse to her, saying.

source_sentence: 昔吾為惡業　　今日自還受
translation: "In the past, I did bad actions, but now I'll take them back myself.

source_sentence: 一切世間苦　　恩愛會離別
translation: all mundane suffering, affection, and separation

source_sentence: 汝當諦思惟　　何應大啼哭
translation: "You must truly consider why you should lament so much.

source_sentence: 城中人民驅其夫妻令出遠外。
translation: The people of the city drove the couple away and made them leave the city.
They wandered around to the city of Vātsī.
They played their lutes, begged for mercy, and begged for their lives.
They then went to the king's palace and stayed in the elephant's stable.
He played his lute and sang, proclaiming his suffering.
When the king heard the music, he vaguely wanted to know what it sounded like.
He sent someone over to see if it was Kunala.
He summoned him and asked him to enter.
When the king saw his son, he was dazed and crippled to the ground.
He raised his voice and shouted, saying, "My body is trembling!
He asked Kunala, "Who disfigured your eyes?
"Who has disfigured your eyes?
You can urgently tell me.
I will punish him for his crime.'
Kunala said.
"Father, don't you hear?
In the past, the Tathāgata still received the results of his actions.
Such a reward was very powerful.
All the noble, virtuous, and venerable are poor and disadvantaged.
There's no way to be freed from it.
My own past actions brought this kind of misfortune.
Don't be troubled, king, and let your heart pine away.
Even though he heard those words, King Aśoka was still burned by the fires of grief.
He still had the fires of grief burning in his heart.
Again, he said to his son.
"Whoever destroyed your eyes?
I will butcher, cut, and grind his body to death!
He then asked Tizhāraka about it.
The king then summoned him.
He said to him.
"Where will you be that you won't sink yourself?
Are you really harboring self-hatred and fraudulent intimacy with outsiders?
What cause did you have to spoil my son's eyes?

source_sentence: 我今當以刀輪劍樹斬截汝身令如塵末。
translation: Now, I will chop off your body with a sword, a wheel, a sword, and a tree and make it look like dust.
I'll discard your corpse in a place that smells foul.
Dung juice and bad poison will fill your mouth.
Then, when Kunala heard the king's words, he arose in great compassion at Tiṣya Rākṣa.
At Tiṣya Rākṣa, he aroused a great compassionate attitude.
He said to his father.
"That foolish man caused this misdeed.
As a result, they've been disgraced.
How could the king, who's wise, agree with them?
If he wants to take further revenge on them now.
We'll surely share their enmity for many eons.
How could there be an end to such continuity?
You should know, Your Majesty.
It's like a cause and sound that's even echoed.
This body thus has suffering as a result.
Moreover, this body is the root of many evils.
That's why the buddhas always make them discard it.
If they make this thing certain and comfortable, why does the wise always become disillusioned?
Why is it that wise people are constantly disillusioned with it?
From this observation, the body is the root of suffering.
It's the accumulation of measureless evil.'
Listen, Great King.
Suppose a worldly infant doesn't understand reality.
They insult their parents and don't have humility or respect for them.

source_sentence: 而此父母豈於其兒起瞋恨耶。
translation: Wouldn't that parent become angry with their child?
All sentient beings are likewise.
They're constantly hindered by affliction.
Foolish and lacking intelligence, they're like small children.
How could they become angry with them?
The king's mind is so venomous that he doesn't accept his words.
He piled up a great amount of fuel and oil and burned it to death.
The crowd then questioned Upagupta.

source_sentence: 以何緣故今此王子生尊貴家而被挑目。
translation: "What is the reason this prince was born into a noble family and has his eyes picked?
The venerable told them.
"Listen well! You will tell him.
Once there was a hunter in [Mokṣala*Nāga].
He was headed up a snowy mountain when there was a huge hailstorm.
There were 500 deer that had fallen into a cave together.
That hunter then wanted to kill them all.
He then thought.
'If we kill them all, they'll all smell bad and rot.'
We'll pick their eyes and eat them gradually.'
Right then, he picked the eyes of 500 deer.
That's the reason they've been punished so far.

source_sentence: 又復久遠迦羅鳩孫佛滅度已後。
translation: Also, long ago, after the extinction of Kakuda-Kumāra, the Buddha died.
The king of that country was named Danyan.
He collected the Buddha's relics and built a seven-jewel stūpa.
Another king later had no respect or faith in his heart.
He destroyed the stūpa and took away the treasures, leaving only dirt and wood.
The people of that country were all sad and wept.
An elderly man's son came and asked what he thought.
The people replied.
"The Krakucchanda stūpa was destroyed.
That was the reason for their lamentation.

source_sentence: 長者子聞尋更修治如前嚴飾。
translation: When the son of the elder heard about it, he had it repaired and adorned like the one before.
He had an image of that Buddha made that had beautiful features.
He then made a vow, saying.

source_sentence: 使我來世如彼世尊得勝解脫。
translation: 'That in a future life I'll be like that Bhagavān and attain excellent liberation.'

source_sentence: 由斯業故生尊貴家得淨妙果。
translation: As a result of this action, I'll be born in a noble family and attain a pure and marvelous result.
So did the retinue of King Asoka.
They all let go of their heavy burdens and were freed from birth and death.
The king's faith is profound and incalculable.
He sees all the ascetics, whether they're old or young.
He greets them, asks questions, respects them, and venerates them.
There was then a minister named Yaśa.
His lack of faith and reverence was fueled by wrong views.
He said.
'King Asoka has very little wisdom!'
He condescends to his noble qualities and venerates young children.
After hearing this, the king ordered his ministers to search for the heads of a hundred animals.
"Each of them asked the ministers to search for the heads of a hundred animals.
He asked Yākṣa alone to search for the head of a human being.
They were all ordered by the king to search for them.
Once they had found them, they all came to the king and presented themselves to him.
The king ordered them to take them to the market and sell them.
In a short time, all the heads were sold together.
There was no one to buy any of Yākṣa's human heads.
After a few days, they were about to rot.
He said, "Great king, this head is hard to sell.
"This head is difficult to sell, and there's still no one who wants to see it.
How could there be anyone who wants to buy it?'
The king asked Yākṣa.
"What's the most valuable thing?
He replied, "Great king.
'It's superior to humans.'
The king said.
"If a person is superior, why isn't he sold?
Yākṣa answered.
"Although a man is noble, he's inferior in death.
The king said.
"My head is the same as this, isn't it?

source_sentence: 夜奢惶怖俛仰而對答言王頭亦同此賤。
translation: Yāśa was frightened, exhorted, and replied, "The king's head is the same as this lowly thing.
The king said.
"My head is humble, if that's the case.
Why do you blame me for honoring a child?
You are a true friend of mine who suffers.

source_sentence: 宜當勸我以危脆頭易堅固首。
translation: You should encourage me to change my fragile head into a strong head.
How could you stop me from being good now?
Then, Minister Yāśa repented himself.
He changed his wrong mind and revered the Three Treasures.
One time, the queen asked Upagupta.
"Who was the greatest donor when the Buddha was here?
The venerable replied.
"That elder Sudatta's generosity was so vast.
He filled it with 10 billion pieces of gold and gave it to the Tathāgata.
The king thought to himself.
'That man was still able to give you that kind of treasure.
Wouldn't it be possible for me to do the same thing now?
He then calculated the things he had given in the past.
That amounted to 9,600,000,000 taels of gold.
When he met with a serious illness, he knew his life was about to end.
He then weeps and becomes very distressed.
There's a minister named Rādhigupta.
He's the boy who was delighted with the past.
Because of this merit, he's been given the position of an assistant minister.
His wisdom is vast, and he's good at discourse.
When he saw the king's distress, he put his palms together and said to the king.
"It's like a great sun when all the people look up to it.
The king's great virtue is likewise.
They are all held in high esteem.
Now, the king is stricken with an illness like a dying sun.
The people of the land are all sad and fearful.
Now, Your Majesty, you must listen to what I've told you.
'The three realms are impermanent, moving, and uninterrupted.'
Even though they're young, strong, and old, they'll all come to a grinding halt.
It's like a mountain of rocks that reaches in all directions.
How can any wise person escape it?
Mundane sentient beings are likewise.
They're subject to the five aggregates and the mountain of death that comes near them.
Suppose they create a hundred thousand methods.
They hide and evade them with various spells.
I've never seen anyone who's been spared this kind of suffering.

source_sentence: 當知世皆無常會必有離。
translation: You should know that the world is impermanent, and there's bound to be an escape.
You should deeply examine this principle.
It's appropriate to suppress it yourself, so why should you worry about it?'
The king told his ministers.
"I don't fear death and love wealth and possessions.
It's because I'm far removed from all the good and noble people.
I've given 10 billion pieces of gold and 400 million pieces have yet to be fulfilled.
It's for this reason that I'm so pitiable.
Rādhigupta said.
"There's a lot in the treasury, so we can give it to him and make it sufficient.

source_sentence: 阿恕伽王即以七寶施雞頭末寺。
translation: King Asoka then gave the temple of Kukkuṭumāra a gift of seven treasures.

source_sentence: 立拘那羅子式摩提以為太子。
translation: He made Kunarazu Shemati the crown prince.
The evil minister said to the prince.

source_sentence: 阿恕伽王命臨欲終散諸庫藏。
translation: "King Asoka is about to scatter the treasury at the end of his life.
If you succeed to the throne, you'll have nothing to use.
Now, you should stop it and not follow his advice.'
Shikamati then believed and accepted the false teaching.
He brought a gold dish for the king to eat.
The king then gave it back to Kukkuṭumārāma.

source_sentence: 後以瓦器半庵摩勒持與王食。
translation: He then gave the king a tile dish and a half-amalā to eat.
The king summoned a group of ministers and asked them.
"Who is the lord of this Jambudvīpa?
The ministers replied.
'Is the king the only one who rules it?'
They replied, "No.

source_sentence: 我唯於此半庵摩勒而得自在。
translation: Only here in half of Amrapāli have I attained mastery.'
He then said.
"My, wealth and power are disgustingly low!
Our position of honor is illusory and will soon vanish.
Even though I'm revered and prominent, I'll eventually fall.
I'm a human being of unsurpassed authority and virtue.
At the end of my days, I'll be poor and have only half a fruit.
Therefore, I know that the world is nothing but a lie.
A foolish man is happy to be reprimanded by a good sage.
He then addressed a group of ministers and spoke a verse, saying.

source_sentence: 諦哉如來教　　所演誠不虛
translation: "Truly, it's the Tathāgata's teaching, and what he teaches is truly not false.

source_sentence: 廣宣生死過　　無可愛樂者
translation: extensively proclaims the faults of birth and death, and that there is nothing to love and enjoy

source_sentence: 我本處尊貴　　威德少倫匹
translation: my original position was one of honor and dignity, and my virtue was not equal to that of any other.

source_sentence: 小王及人民　　無一不瞻仰
translation: There is no one the young king and his people do not look up to

source_sentence: 今日福將盡　　飢困自纏逼
translation: Today, merit will be exhausted, and hunger and distress will be self-tethered.

source_sentence: 猶如暴河流　　觸山無復勢
translation: just like a raging river that touches a mountain without further momentum

source_sentence: 我昔濟貧乏　　拯救諸苦惱
translation: I helped the poor and needy in the past and saved them from suffering and distress.

source_sentence: 如何於今日　　自處斯卑賤
translation: how could we have placed ourselves in such a lowly position today?

source_sentence: 始知尊貴位　　易滅不堅牢
translation: first realizes that the exalted position is easily extinguished and not firmly established

source_sentence: 解脫寂靜樂　　唯是最為快
translation: the quiescent bliss of liberation is the only thing that is most pleasant
After speaking this verse, he ordered a minister.
"Take this fruit to Kukkuṭārāmaji.
He said, "As I said.
"King Asoka saluted the feet of the saṃgha.

source_sentence: 我唯於此半菴摩勒而得自在。
translation: 'Only here, at half an amal, have I attained mastery.
All that I possess has been lost.
Although this fruit is the last of the gifts, I hope the saṃgha will sympathize with my poor and suffering.
Please let the saṃgha take pity on my poverty and suffering.
Accept it for them.
The superior seat, Yaśas, addressed the monks.
"All of you should observe this.

source_sentence: 阿恕伽王受福快樂總御天下。
translation: 'King Asoka is blessed and happy, and he has dominion over the whole world.
Now, he's been taken over by a group of ministers.
Only the half-fruits attain their own portion of freedom.
You should know that birth and death are very discomforting.
Wealth and possessions and the five desires will soon disintegrate.
Their authority and sovereignty will soon cease.
Gee, the three realms are difficult to abide in for a long time.
I then ordered the preceptor to grind this fruit.
Put it in a dish.
That way, all the saṃgha will be able to make offerings to it.
King Aśoka was about to die.
He asked Rādhigupta.
"Who has attained mastery in this Jambudvīpa?
Rādhigup said.
"Only the king.
Having heard that, he then rose and put his palms together and looked around.
He got up, put his palms together, and looked around in all directions.
He said.
"Only the treasury is excluded.

source_sentence: 今以四海一切大地悉施佛僧。
translation: 'Now, I'll give the Buddha and the saṃgha all of the earth in the four seas.'
and the merits of what he's done since the distant past.
He doesn't seek birth and death, nor does he turn the wheel of Indra's guidance.
May I quickly realize the fruit of the path in my next birthplace.
The letter, seal, and title were handed over to Rādhigupta.
His breath then gave out, and he was pronounced dead.
He was reborn in the adorned funeral of the wheel-turning king.
Thus did Venerable Upagupta.
He developed the king's mind and increased his faith.
He had good methods for teaching sentient beings.

source_sentence: 後復一時宿羅城中有一商主名為天護。
translation: Another time, there was a merchant in the city of Sugara named Tianhuo.
He was greatly venerated and believed in him.
He wanted to enter the ocean and search for treasures.

source_sentence: 若海迴還為僧造作般遮于瑟。
translation: If he returned to the ocean, he built a monk's hall for the saṃgha.
He went to the ocean to gather treasure and returned home in peace.
He then got the intention to set up a great almsgiving.
A monk or nun attains arhatship.
He observed which of the crowd was a field of merit.
Again, he considered.
"Which one is the head of the saṃgha?
It's the head of the saṃgha who sees the arhats and trainees.
He's cut off the afflictions and defilements and is worthy of offerings.'
He observes a monk named Ashara.
He's the most eminent among the saṃgha before he attains liberation.
The monks and nuns then went over to him and said.
"Now, great man, you should adorn yourself.
The monk then didn't understand his intention.
He then put on clean robes, shaved his hair, and took a bath.
Again, at some point later, the monk and nun spoke again.
The monk and nun then went back to Sala and told him.
"Teach him to adorn himself.
Asura then became extremely angry.
'I've followed your words with great dignity and cleanliness.
What's so ugly and unpleasant about it that you would say that again?
The monk and nun said.
"Great virtuous one, you should know this.
'This conventional adornment is not the Buddha's teaching.'
The Buddha's method of adornment is defined as attaining the four fruits.
Amazing, Mañjuśrī, how little it means.
The elder gods and guardians wanted to set up a large assembly.
The people who would accept his offerings would be many good and noble people.
You're the head of the saṃgha and haven't yet escaped birth and death.
You first accepted the offerings with a contaminated mind.
Now, therefore, I want to awaken you to this.

source_sentence: 阿沙羅聞慘然悲泣自惟。
translation: Asaru was saddened by what he heard and weeping, he said.
"How could an old man end the contaminants?
The monks and nuns said.
'There's no time like the present when the Buddha's teaching is not available, so why don't you go to Upagupta?'
Perhaps you should go to see Upagupta.
He will surely save him from suffering.'
The monk then went to Upagupta.
It was just as the saṃgha was bathing that they both appeared miraculously.
Rejoicing, Asaru spoke a verse, saying.

source_sentence: 和合共一處　　跏趺若龍盤
translation: "They are all together in one place, cross-legged like a dragon's coil.

source_sentence: 咸皆入寂定　　寂然不傾動
translation: all enter into the concentration of quiescence and remain calm and unmoving

source_sentence: 普放淨光明　　猶如百千日
translation: a hundred thousand suns are shining like a hundred thousand rays of pure light

source_sentence: 雖同人形類　　功德甚高遠
translation: even though they are of human form, their merit is very lofty
Upagupta saw how compliant he was.
He then taught the Dharma for them and became an arhat.
At the time, there was another Upagupta.
He said to the Brāhmaṇa.
"There's no self.
The Brāhmaṇa said.
"Who said this?
He replied.
"Gupta always proclaims that there's no self.
He simply says 'I am' in a provisional sense of combination.
The Brāhmaṇa then went to the venerable.
Upagupta knew his thoughts.
He was mindful that he would then proclaim for him that all things are without self.
It's like the sound of a cry rising from an empty mountain.
When you truly observe and consider it, you see that it's unobtainable.
It's simply the result of the union of the five aggregates.
Who among the wise would suppose that to be true?

source_sentence: 時婆羅門即便開悟成須陀洹。
translation: Even then, the Brāhmaṇa was enlightened and became a stream entrant.
He had them leave home and attain the path of the arhat.

source_sentence: 有族姓子詣憂波毱多出家學道。
translation: There was a clansman who went to Upagupta, left home, and trained on the path.
He always liked to sleep and was lazy and indolent.
Even though he preached to them, he got nothing.
The Bhagavān instructed him to sit under a tree and meditate.
He then went back to sleep under the tree.
Gupta was transformed into a deep pit a thousand feet deep.
The monk was terrified when he saw that.
He focused his mind on Upagupta.
The venerable then transformed himself into a path.
He allowed the monk to cross through it.
He thought to himself, "My teacher has spared me this misfortune.
Upagupta then said to him.
"This fear is trivial and unspeakable.
The three realms are subject to the suffering of birth, old age, illness, and death.
They always follow their travellers and are never abandoned.
There are a hundred million kinds of pain and suffering in hell.
Such a fear is even greater than this pit.
That monk then stopped sleeping and slept.
He diligently contemplates and attains arhatship.
In a country to the east, there was a clansman.
They believed in and enjoyed the Buddha's teaching, left home, and trained on the path.
He was able to perform tasks well, and nothing was left undone.
After passing through much time, he again became weary.
He went to Venerable Upagupta.
That venerable man observed and knew this monk.
He knew that this monk hadn't yet attained the path because his merits weren't complete.
He then made him a monk who marched around and taught him.
He was instructed to go into the city and search for him everywhere.
An elder saw him and asked him about it.
He replied, "Sir!
"Venerable Gupta asked me to teach them.
Who is this devout believer in the city?
The elder then said.
"Be careful not to leave anything else.
Everything that's needed.
You must give them to each other.
He prepared the meal for them.

source_sentence: 比丘得已於上座前持食長跪。
translation: After he did, the monk took his food and knelt down in front of the elder's seat.
All the monks make a vow for that purpose.
After fulfilling the vow, he became an arhat.
There was a monk who was naturally addicted to food and drink.
Because of this craving, he couldn't attain the Way.
Upagupta asked him to come to his room.
He gave him some scented milk and milk powder.
He told him to wait until it was cold, then he could eat it.
The monk blew on the coagulated milk, and it turned cold.
He told the Bhagavān that the curd was already cold.
The venerable told him.
"Even though this coagulated milk is cold, your desire for it to be hot should be heated.
You should use contemplative water to quench the fire in your mind.
Again, he put in an empty vessel and made it spit out food.
After spitting out the food, you should then make him eat it again.
The monk answered, "How can you eat saliva when it's combined with food?
"How could we eat it if we combined saliva with spit?
The venerable said.
'All food and drink is no different from this.
You didn't examine it and falsely became attached to it.
Now, you must examine the perception that food is impure.
That's how you'll explain the teaching and attain the path of the arhat.
There was a monk who deeply desired the body.
Because he loved the body, he wanted to go home again.
He left Upagupta and stayed at a celestial shrine.
The venerable then transformed into a yakṣa.
He carried the dead man to this celestial temple.
Then another ghost came from behind.
The two ghosts then fought over the dead body together.
They had a dispute that they couldn't resolve on their own.
The former demon said.
"I have a witness.
They then asked together.
"Who's the dead corpse?
Terrified, the person then thinks to himself.
'There's no doubt that I'm certainly going to die now.
I'd better tell the truth and have the corpse slaughtered.
He said to the ghost in front of him.
"This is your corpse!
The latter ghost gets angry and pulls out his hands and feet.
The former ghost then takes the dead body and replaces it.
Its body is completely reborn like the original.
The two spirits then shared the rest of the flesh.
After they finished eating the flesh, they then left.
That person then stopped loving himself and stopped his mind.
He returned to the venerable and left home to pursue his studies.
Soon afterward, he became an arhat.
In southern India, there was a clansman who left home and trained on the path.
He left home and trained on the path.
He was fond of bathing himself and coating himself with incense.
He liked nice food and drink and was physically robust.
He couldn't attain the way.
He went to the Bhagavān to seek acceptance of the excellent teaching.
Upagupta observed this man.
'Because he's attached to his body, the contaminants won't end.'
He said to the monk.
'I'll teach you the Dharma if you accept my teaching.
He was transformed into a great tree and made to climb it.
On the four sides, he transforms it into a deep pit a thousand feet deep.
He causes his right hand to be released ... and even his whole body to be released.
That person then parts with his body and his life.
He releases his hands and feet as far as they'll go, and then he reaches the ground.
He doesn't see the deep pit or the large tree.
He teaches the essentials of the Dharma to attain the path of the arhat.
There was a monk whose heart was so stingy and greedy that he couldn't reach the path because of this cause.
Because of these causes, he couldn't follow the path.
Upagupta instructed him to give alms.
He replied.
"What kind of gift do I need because I'm poor?

source_sentence: 憂波毱多遣二弟子坐其左右。
translation: Upagupta sent two of his disciples to sit at his left and right.
A light emanated from their bodies.
The monk rejoiced and gave less food.
When he later obtains a good meal, he becomes delighted.
He thinks, "Suppose he says.
'A little generosity still yields a lot of rewards.
If he gives more, the reward is immeasurable.'
He then refutes his stinginess.
He explains the profound teaching for them.
At that time, he'll attain the fruit of the arhat.
There was a clansman who left home and trained on the path.
Upagupta explains the essentials of the Dharma for him.
He then discovers the truth and attains stream entry.
He had this thought, saying.
'I've cut the three bonds, what more do I want to advance to?'
My freedom to roam would reach the limit of seven lifetimes.'
The Bhagavān told him.
"The principle of birth-and-death is very unpleasant and base.
It's like excrement that stinks no matter how much it is.
Even as he was about to go to the village of Candra, he saw a little boy with bad sores on his body.
He saw a small child with a bad sore on its body.
The blood of insects and worms coming out of his body was very painful.
He asked the monk.
"Have you seen this little boy?
That little boy is a stream-winner.
When the Buddha was here in the past, there was a arhat.
His body was small and he had ulcers.
When he scratched it, it made a sound.
Vairocana was angry and said.
"Now, you have maggot sores on your body, don't you?
Perhaps you should go out to the village of Candradhara.
The arhat said.
"Now, you've committed a sin. Don't say that.
Vairocana then even repented and cultivated himself to become a stream entrant.
He diligently cultivated and became a stream entrant.
Later, he became lazy and didn't seek advancement.
That's why he was born in this family and suffered these kinds of hardships.
Again, he went on a minor journey.
He saw a man being burned by fire.
His body was scorched, and the pain was unbearable.
He turned further ahead and saw another person.

source_sentence: 犯王憲法以身貫著大木標上。
translation: He violated the king's constitution by putting his body through a large wooden lantern.
He made a loud, lamenting [mouth*testicle] and was extremely distressed.
It was then that the venerable asked the monk.
"Don't you see these two people?
The monk said.
"Yes, I have seen them.
The venerable told him.
"The person in front of him is a sakṛd-āgāmin.
The one seen after him is non-returner.
They're all lazy and don't seek advancement.
That's why they're born among humans and suffer this pain.

source_sentence: 是故汝今宜自精懃早求解脫。
translation: It's therefore appropriate for you to exert yourself and seek liberation early.
After hearing this, the monk cultivated it day and night.
Soon, he attains the path of the arhat.

source_sentence: 尊者即為真陀羅子說諸法要成阿那含。
translation: The venerable then taught the essentials of the Dharma for the true Dharma child to become an arhat.
At the end of his life, he was reborn in the Pure Land.

source_sentence: 摩突羅國有一長者生育一子。
translation: In Mathurā, there was an elder who gave birth to a son.
He was one year old when his life ended.
He did so in order up to six elders.
After he's born for one year, his life ends again.
Finally, he's born again to a senior citizen.
At the first seven years of age, he becomes a thief and leaves.

source_sentence: 憂波毱多觀此小兒應現得道。
translation: Upagupta observes that this youngster should now attain the way.
He disguised himself as four soldiers and wanted to capture the thief.
The thief was terrified, begged for mercy, and venerated him.
He explained the teaching and the essentials for becoming a stream entrant.
He took this little boy and gave him to Upagupta.
The venerable then saved this boy.
He and the gang of thieves were all made to leave home.
He taught them the wondrous Dharma and attained the path of the arhat.
He said to the boy.

source_sentence: 今可觀察汝之親族而化度之。
translation: "Now, you can observe your relatives and save them.
He then observed his parents from seven generations.
They were sad and wept, remembering their son.
He then went to their home and spoke.
"Elder!
"I'm your son.

source_sentence: 莫大愁惱為宣法要得初道果。
translation: Don't be so worried, for the sake of proclaiming the essentials of the Dharma and attaining the first fruit of the path.
The next sixth family is likewise.
There's a clansman who believes in the Buddha and leaves home.
He sits in meditation and attains the four mundane meditations.
He claims to have finally attained the fruit of the arhat.
Upagupta had a good method for doing so.
He causes that monk to go to another village.
He then transformed himself into an estimator in the middle path.
Again, he appeared as a group of 500 thieves.
They all came together as a gang to plunder the valet.
They killed, injured, and stabbed him all over the ground.
That monk then became very afraid.
Even though he knew on his own that he wasn't an arhat, he thought.
Again, he thought.
'I'm not a arhat, but I'm an arhat.'
It was then that the Bhagavān passed away and broke up.
An elderly woman said to that monk.
"Please, Mañjuśrī, let's go together.
The monk answered, "The Buddha won't listen to me walking with a woman.
"The Buddha won't listen to me walking with a woman.
The elder woman said.
"I wish the great virtuous one would follow me.
The monk took pity on her and looked at each other as he walked.
The venerable then again transformed into a large river.
The woman said, "Mañjuśrī!
'Can you cross it with me?'
The monk was below, but the woman was upstream.
The woman was upstream.
The woman then got submerged and fell into the river.
She said, "Great man!
"Help me in this difficult situation.
The monk then pulled her out and let her out.
He gave rise to a thought of fine, smooth remembrance and desire.
Even though he knew for himself that he wasn't an anāgāmin, he became extremely attached to this woman.
He became extremely attached to this woman.
He wanted to share her company, and he was about to go to a place of interruption.
Only then did he see that it was Upagupta.
He became greatly ashamed, bowed his head, and stood up.
The venerable spoke.
'You used to call yourself an arhat.
Why did you want to do such a bad thing?
You were about to go to the monastery and teach him to repent.
He taught him the essentials of the Dharma to attain the arhat path.
There was a monk who did an impure observation.
He said that he had attained the noble path because he had temporarily stopped rising from his bonds.
Upagupta told him.
"Monks!
'Could you go there to the country of Gandhāra?
Accept the teaching and travel to that land.

source_sentence: 於此國中有一長者名迦羅和。
translation: In that country, there was an elder named Kālapatra.
He had given birth to a daughter who was quite extraordinary in appearance.

source_sentence: 時此比丘即往其舍而從乞食。
translation: That monk then went to her house and begged for food.
The woman carried the food out, showing her teeth and smiling.
After he saw her, the monk became desirous.
That's because he's been practicing meditation on impurity.
He took the shape of the woman's teeth and observed that they were white bones.
Because of this observation, he attains the path of the arhat.
He reproaches himself for his original mind and says, "Verse.

source_sentence: 外現於賢善　　內實多染著
translation: "Outwardly, he shows himself to be a good man, but inside he really has many defiled attachments.

source_sentence: 見其實相故　　心即得解脫
translation: because of seeing their true characteristics, the mind attains liberation
In Mathurā, there was an elderly man's son.
After marrying a new wife, he had this thought in his mind, saying.

source_sentence: 我於佛法欲求出家便辭父母。
translation: 'Because I want to leave home because of the Buddha's teachings, I'll leave my parents.'
The parents replied.
"My only son would die, but I wouldn't let him go.
How could it be possible for him to survive?'
The son then said.
'If I don't let go of him, I'll never eat.'
He then stopped eating.
From the first day until the end of the seventh day, his parents were afraid of his death.
His parents, fearing death, said to him.
"I will grant your wish.
Only meet me after you leave home.
The son was greatly pleased, so he left.
He went to Upagupta and begged him to leave home.
His Holiness then readmitted him to the path.
He then said to himself.
'I had a promise with my parents in the past.'
He left the Venerable and went to his home.
He met his parents and his wife.
She said to him.
"If you don't return them, you'll be left for dead.
The monk repented and then wanted to renounce the precepts.
He went to his master's office, saying that he wanted to return home.
Gupta told him.
"We'll wait until tomorrow.
He then took his teacher's advice and stayed at the temple for the night.

source_sentence: 尊者於夜為之現夢使此比丘見到本家。
translation: During the night, the Bhagavān showed him a dream that caused this monk to see his family.

source_sentence: 其妻是日尋便命終父母親族嚴辦葬具送其屍骸置於塚間。
translation: His wife then found him and ordered his parents and relatives to finish preparing his body for burial and to put it in a tomb.
In a moment, the stink and rotten worms and maggots emerged together.
Bones and flesh were scattered, and foxes and wolves were fighting over it.
She was startled and went to tell her teacher.
The teacher then told him.
"Can you go and see if it's really a dream?
Riding on the teacher's supernormal powers, he suddenly arrived at his house.
His wife had died just as he had seen in the dream.
He thought about it, observed it, and became profoundly disgusted.
He then attained the path of an arhat.

source_sentence: 憂留陀山有一老虎生於二子。
translation: On Mount Meruḍa, there was a tiger that gave birth to two sons.
They were starving and desperate, and then they died.
Without their mother, the two sons were left in dire straits.
Upagupta went to them.
He gave them food and spoke a verse for them, saying.

source_sentence: 諸行無常　　是生滅法　　生滅滅已　寂滅為樂日日與食為說此偈。
translation: 'Actions are impermanent. They are the law of arising and ceasing. After arising and ceasing, cessation is bliss.' Day by day, he gave them food and spoke this verse.
Those two tigers looked for him and then his life ended.
They were born in the Brāhmaṇa household in the country of Tura.
Upagupta went to their house.
He said, "He's alone, with no companions.
The Brāhmaṇa said.
"Why is it that you're walking alone?
He replied, "Don't be afraid, sir.
'I'm a monk with few servants.'
The brāhmaṇa said.
"My wife is expecting a baby.
'If a boy is born, he'll give his respects.'
She later gave birth to two sons with good looks.
Suppose Upagupta goes to ask for them.
The Brāhmaṇa said.
"The sons are both young.
If they grow up, they'll surely be given.'
When he was eight years old, he again went to ask for them.
He then gave the venerable the older son.
The younger one then said.
"I can be allowed to leave.
They were engaged in a dispute, and each wanted to leave home.

source_sentence: 憂波毱言此二子者皆應得道。
translation: Upagupta said, "These two sons will both attain the way.

source_sentence: 時婆羅門俱以二子付於尊者。
translation: The Brāhmaṇa then took those two sons and gave them to the venerable.
He told them to leave home and attain the status of arhat.
He then asked them to gather campaka flowers.
He replied, "Great teacher!
"This tree is too tall for me to reach.
The Bhagavān said.
"Are you gods without miraculous powers?

source_sentence: 時二沙彌即昇虛空採花奉獻。
translation: The two novices then rose into the sky to gather flowers and present them to him.
The venerable monk and his disciples stood together.
They looked at their spiritual virtue and praised it as unprecedented.
Skt. Gupta said.
"These two ascetics were the son of a hungry tiger.
You used to dislike me for feeding this tiger.
Today, you might observe its miraculous powers.
After hearing this, the disciple had a peculiar thought.
"In the southern country of India, there was a man.
He was involved in sexual misconduct with another woman.
His mother even severely rebuked him.
"Now, you should know.
'The law of sexual desire has many faults.
Also, because of this, there's nothing bad that you won't do.
In the future, you'll surely be born in a place of suffering and distress.'
The son then became angry and killed his mother.

source_sentence: 往至他家求彼女人竟不獲得。
translation: He went to another family and asked for that woman, but he couldn't get her.

source_sentence: 心生厭悔於佛法中出家為道。
translation: He became disillusioned and left home to follow the path of the Buddhadharma.
He didn't long memorize the Tripiṭaka and become well-versed in it.
He was skilled in speech and had many retinues.
He and his disciples went to the venerable.

source_sentence: 憂波毱多觀察彼人躬造逆罪無道果分。
translation: Upagupta observed that person personally committing a heinous act that had no part in the fruit of the path.
He remained silent and didn't speak to him.
The monk of the Tripiṭaka knew the depth of his offense.
He also saw that it wasn't right and returned to his lodging.

source_sentence: 有一比丘坐禪思惟得世俗定。
translation: There was a monk who sat in meditation and contemplated and attained worldly concentration.
He even claimed to have realized the four paths.
Again, he was sitting under a tree for a short time.

source_sentence: 憂波毱多化作比丘而往其所。
translation: Upagupta took the form of a monk and went to him.
They exchanged greetings and sat to one side.
The transformation monk asked him.
"From whom did he leave home?
He replied.
"My teacher's name is Upagupta.
He praised him and said.
"Great! Good for you!
Your teacher is the signless, beautiful Buddha.
Again, he said to the monk.
"Which sūtra are you reciting?
He replied.
"I recite the scriptures of the Tripiṭaka.
The transformation monk then asked.
"What path have you realized?
He replied.
'I've attained the fruit of the arhat.'
What did you realize as the fruit?
He replied.
Mundane concentration.'
The conjured-up monk said.
"If someone uses conventional concentration to realize the path, then it's false.
That would be a falsehood.
After hearing this, the monk deeply regretted it.
He concentrated his efforts and attained arhatship.
In the country of Kāśmīra, there was a monk named Shanwei.
His name was Shanjian.
He had attained worldly concentration and possessed the five supernormal powers.
When there's no rain, he can cause water to pour down.
He arouses pride in his spiritual superiority and says he's realized the noble path.
Upagupta then even created it.
There was a drought for 12 years.
The people were terrified and begged Venerable Upagupta.
The venerable told them.
"I can't do it.
In the country of Kāśmīra, there was a well-seeing monk.
He had the most excellent psychic powers and was very capable of bringing rain.
The people all went there to ask him to do so.

source_sentence: 時此比丘即以神力飛空而至。
translation: That monk then flew into the air with supernormal powers and arrived.
He invited sweet rain to pour down on them at the right time.
The people rejoiced and made great offerings.
After making the offerings, they then became proud.
Again, he thought.
'Arhats don't have the heart to be proud of him.'
He then went to the venerable begging for pity and repentance.
He taught the essentials of the Dharma to attain the arhat path.
In southern India, there was a monk.
He had few desires and was satisfied with crude clothing.
His body was too weak to attain the path.
Upagupta observed this person.
'He should now attain the path.'
It's because he's physically weak.
He prepares robes, rubs his feet with scented oil, and then attains the arhat path.
He should then attain the path of an arhat.
Thus, he trains and liberates measureless sentient beings.
They'll all attain the fruit of the arhat.
One of those who attain the path has one piece of wood.
He fills a stone room with a length of four inches.
The room is six feet high, and so is the length and breadth of the room.

source_sentence: 於是名稱滿閻浮提世皆號為無相好佛。
translation: He then fills it with names, and the whole world of Jambudvīpa is called the formless, beautiful Buddha.
After fulfilling his mission, he then thought to himself.
'Now, I've finished making offerings to the Buddha with the Dharma.
It will bring benefit, comfort, and happiness to him.

source_sentence: 同梵行者使諸四輩獲大饒益。
translation: Those who practice the same celibacy will cause the four groups to obtain great benefit.
They will promote the correct teaching and never end it.
It's appropriate to extinguish nirvāṇa when it arrives.'
He told the crowd.
"Seven days from now, I will attain nirvāṇa.

source_sentence: 爾時即集十方羅漢及諸學人。
translation: At that point, they immediately gathered arhats and people of learning in ten directions.
Those who were pure adherents of the precepts were incalculable.
There were measureless hundreds of thousands of laymen.

source_sentence: 尊者於是飛身虛空現十八變。
translation: The venerable then flew his body through space and showed 18 transformations.
He caused the four crowds to give rise to great faith.
He attains extinction in nirvāṇa without remainder.
He used a coffin in his abode to offer up his jhāpita.
One hundred thousand arhats also enter nirvāṇa.
People and gods weep and wail and are saddened.
They all collected the relics and erected stūpas to make offerings.
Fufazang yinnian zhuan, vol. 4
